segments.en: Linked Discourses 11
3. The Third Chapter
22. Ugly
Near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove.

segments.pli: “bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, aññataro yakkho dubbaṇṇo okoṭimako sakkassa devānamindassa āsane nisinno ahosi.
segments.en: “Once upon a time, mendicants, there was a native spirit who was ugly and deformed. He sat on the throne of Sakka, lord of gods.

segments.pli: Tatra sudaṃ, bhikkhave, devā tāvatiṃsā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti:
segments.en: But the gods of the Thirty-Three complained, grumbled, and objected,
‘It’s incredible, it’s amazing!

segments.pli: Ayaṃ yakkho dubbaṇṇo okoṭimako sakkassa devānamindassa āsane nisinno’ti.
segments.en: This ugly and deformed spirit is sitting on the throne of Sakka, the lord of gods.’

segments.pli: Yathā yathā kho, bhikkhave, devā tāvatiṃsā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti tathā tathā so yakkho abhirūpataro ceva hoti dassanīyataro ca pāsādikataro ca.
segments.en: But the more the gods complained, the more attractive, good-looking, and lovely that spirit became.

segments.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, devā tāvatiṃsā yena sakko devānamindo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: So the gods went up to Sakka and told him what had happened, adding,

segments.pli: ‘idha te, mārisa, aññataro yakkho dubbaṇṇo okoṭimako sakkassa devānamindassa āsane nisinno.
Tatra sudaṃ, mārisa, devā tāvatiṃsā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti:
Ayaṃ yakkho dubbaṇṇo okoṭimako sakkassa devānamindassa āsane nisinno”ti.
Yathā yathā kho, mārisa, devā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti tathā tathā so yakkho abhirūpataro ceva hoti dassanīyataro ca pāsādikataro cāti.
So hi nūna, mārisa, kodhabhakkho yakkho bhavissatī’ti.
segments.en: ‘Surely, good sir, that must be the anger-eating spirit!’

segments.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo yena so kodhabhakkho yakkho tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā dakkhiṇajāṇumaṇḍalaṃ pathaviyaṃ nihantvā yena so kodhabhakkho yakkho tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā tikkhattuṃ nāmaṃ sāveti:
segments.en: Then Sakka went up to that spirit, arranged his robe over one shoulder, knelt with his right knee on the ground, raised his joined palms toward the anger-eating spirit, and pronounced his name three times:
‘Good sir, I am Sakka, lord of gods! Good sir, I am Sakka, the lord of gods!’

segments.pli: Yathā yathā kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo nāmaṃ sāvesi tathā tathā so yakkho dubbaṇṇataro ceva ahosi okoṭimakataro ca.
segments.en: But the more Sakka pronounced his name, the uglier and more deformed the spirit became,

segments.pli: Dubbaṇṇataro ceva hutvā okoṭimakataro ca tatthevantaradhāyīti.
segments.en: until eventually it vanished right there.

segments.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo sake āsane nisīditvā deve tāvatiṃse anunayamāno tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
segments.en: Then Sakka, lord of gods, guiding the gods of the Thirty-Three, recited this verse:
‘My mind isn’t easily upset;
I’m not easily drawn into the maelstrom.
I don’t get angry for long,
anger doesn’t last in me.
When I do get angry I don’t speak harshly,
nor do I advertise my own virtues.
I carefully restrain myself
out of regard for my own welfare.’”

suttaplex.blurb: When an ugly spirit takes Sakka’s throne, the gods were outraged. But the more they complained, the prettier he became. Sakka realized this was the so-called “anger eating spirit”, and treated him with kindness and respect.
